quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We have 34 million users globally. There's people everywhere learning to code on Replit, building startups, building personal software, personal tools.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: A concrete scale data point that signals broad adoption and diverse real-world use cases beyond just professional developers.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Typically, you're bottlenecked where your ideas are not fitting in because they need to be made and they need to be made quickly. Now, you open up that bottleneck. So now actually making things is a lot easier. Actually, you become limited by how fast you can generate ideas.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: A mental model for how AI tooling shifts the constraint in product building from execution speed to idea generation throughput.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I could imagine whatever five years from now, someone running a billion-dollar company with zero employees where it's like the support is handled by AI, the development is handled by AI, and you're just building and creating this thing.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: A provocative, counterintuitive prediction that reframes how founders should think about leverage, headcount, and company-building in an AI-native world.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: One of the reasons for the difficulty is that it is very fragmented, so you would need to download what's called an IDE. It's basically a code editor. You need to download the runtime, basically Python or JavaScript, need to figure out a package manager to configure your kind of open source packages, and once you've done all of that, you need to figure out how to deploy it, how to share it.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: A practical breakdown of the end-to-end friction points that block software creation—useful for diagnosing where tools can remove onboarding and shipping bottlenecks.

quotes.topic_title: What Replit is and why it exists
quotes.text: One of the reasons for the difficulty is that it is very fragmented, so you would need to download what's called an IDE. It's basically a code editor. You need to download the runtime, basically Python or JavaScript, need to figure out a package manager to configure your kind of open source packages, and once you've done all of that, you need to figure out how to deploy it, how to share it.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: A concrete breakdown of the fragmented toolchain that creates friction in software development—useful for diagnosing onboarding and DX bottlenecks.

quotes.topic_title: What Replit is and why it exists
quotes.text: So it's a very hard process, and that's one of the ways where people get stuck and never learn how to code because it just feels like this cumbersome IT process.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Highlights a counterintuitive barrier to learning: tooling/setup friction, not the act of programming itself.

quotes.topic_title: What Replit is and why it exists
quotes.text: And so the vision for Replit has always been is like, okay, making software is fun, is great, more people should do it, but so for more people to do it, it needs to be easier to do, it needs to be in one place, and it needs to be learnable.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: A simple product strategy framework: unify the workflow into one place and optimize for learnability to expand the creator base.

quotes.topic_title: What Replit is and why it exists
quotes.text: It is I think one of the more easier IDEs/ environment/deployment environment on the internet, and I think we make it really easy for people to just jump in even without prior experience of coding, especially now with the new AI products that we built.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Actionable positioning: reduce time-to-first-success so beginners can start immediately, amplified by AI assistance.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're building a SaaS app, at some point, your customers will start asking for enterprise features like SAML authentication and SCIM provisioning.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights a predictable inflection point for SaaS teams: enterprise readiness becomes a customer-driven requirement.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Their APIs are easy to understand so that you can ship quickly and get back to building other features.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Actionable product-selection heuristic: prioritize tools that minimize integration time and opportunity cost.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Warrant's product is based on a groundbreaking authorization system called Zanzibar, which was originally designed for Google to power Google Docs and YouTube.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Concrete example of leveraging proven, large-scale design patterns for authorization in modern products.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It's a drop-in replacement for Auth0 and supports up to 1 million monthly active users for free.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Specific pricing/scale data point that can materially affect build-vs-buy and vendor evaluation decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We have 34 million users globally.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Key scale metric that contextualizes Replit’s adoption and traction worldwide.

quotes.topic_title: Replit scale, users, and adoption stories
quotes.text: We have 34 million users globally.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: A concrete scale data point that signals broad adoption and product-market fit across geographies.

quotes.topic_title: Replit scale, users, and adoption stories
quotes.text: More recently, we've been expanding to companies. We released our kind of B2B package in July, and that's been growing really fast.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Shows a clear expansion path from individual users to enterprise adoption, with a specific launch milestone and growth signal.

quotes.topic_title: Replit scale, users, and adoption stories
quotes.text: And the best part of it is someone in the... replied to him and they're like, "You have to launch an app. You have to host it somewhere. You have to build a database. You have to deploy it. There's no way to do that." And he's like, "No, that's exactly what Replit did."
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A vivid user story that highlights the core value proposition: removing the traditional infrastructure hurdles to shipping software.

quotes.topic_title: Replit scale, users, and adoption stories
quotes.text: The surprising thing about an 11-year-old building an app is not so much even the coding, it is like all the nonsense around it, and so we just abstract all that away.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: A counterintuitive product insight: the real barrier to building isn’t writing code, but the surrounding operational complexity—so eliminate it.

quotes.topic_title: Competitive landscape and Replit’s differentiation
quotes.text: Again, we go back to this idea of end-to-end platform for making software. So that's from writing code all the way to deploying it, and monetizing it and all of that.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Defines Replit’s differentiation as an end-to-end platform spanning the full software lifecycle, not just coding.

quotes.topic_title: Competitive landscape and Replit’s differentiation
quotes.text: Cursor is a fork of VS Code that's made that has really awesome AI tools, but that's an editor. You still need runtime, you still need a deployment environment. Actually, quite a few users use Cursor in tandem with Replit, because Replit just simplifies the runtime and deployment environment.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Actionable competitive positioning: pair best-in-class AI editing with a platform that removes runtime/deploy friction.

quotes.topic_title: Competitive landscape and Replit’s differentiation
quotes.text: If you're at a big company, it's very easy to bring a new editor and start coding with it. It's quite hard to bring something that's quite opinionated about everything from how the code runs to how the code deploys, but that's the trade-off we're willing to make is like yeah, we're not going to get into the enterprise main software development pipeline, but we want to empower everyone to be able to build software, and that means product managers, designers.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Contrarian go-to-market trade-off: being opinionated hurts enterprise adoption but enables broader empowerment beyond engineers.

quotes.topic_title: Competitive landscape and Replit’s differentiation
quotes.text: We have operations people, sales ops, HR ops. We have lawyers using Replit, and so it is democratizing the act of software engineering.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Concrete examples of non-engineering functions building software, illustrating the “democratization” thesis.

quotes.topic_title: Live demo: prompting an app into existence
quotes.text: I feel like there's so much talk about AI and what it's doing and people keep reading about, oh, AI can do this and AI can do that, and I feel like not many people actually see this stuff in action, especially the most cutting edge stuff.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights the practical gap between AI hype and actually watching/learning from real workflows, motivating demos as a learning tool.

quotes.topic_title: Live demo: prompting an app into existence
quotes.text: most recently, and this is how Replit became a thousand times easier, is you can just describe what you want to make.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: A concrete methodology shift: moving from choosing stacks/config to starting with natural-language intent.

quotes.topic_title: Live demo: prompting an app into existence
quotes.text: There's different styles of using Replit agents. I often go with minimalist prompts. That's also how I code as well. I have a vague idea for what I want to build and iterate from there. Other people, product managers like to write PRDs and more descriptive things, and you can do either of those things.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Offers an actionable prompting framework: choose between iterative “minimalist” prompting vs PRD-like specification depending on your working style.

quotes.topic_title: Live demo: prompting an app into existence
quotes.text: The AI is also suggesting, adding comment threads, implementing email notifications, and so I can select those and it's being creative, it's telling me what else I could build, but for now, I'm just going to go with a prototype and then we can assess from there.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Demonstrates a practical product-building loop: accept AI-generated enhancements selectively, but prioritize shipping a prototype first and iterating.

quotes.topic_title: Live demo: prompting an app into existence
quotes.text: it's actually quite fun and edifying to watch it build this, because you can really start to learn how to structure web apps.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: A learning tactic: treat the agent’s step-by-step build process as an educational scaffold for understanding app architecture.

quotes.topic_title: Watching the agent build full-stack components
quotes.text: It's created a Postgres database. Obviously, when we're building a full-stack application, you need to be able to save things.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Grounds full-stack app building in a concrete requirement (persistence) and shows the agent handling real infrastructure setup.

quotes.topic_title: Watching the agent build full-stack components
quotes.text: it's actually quite fun and edifying to watch it build this, because you can really start to learn how to structure web apps.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Positions “watching the agent work” as a learning methodology for practitioners to internalize app structure.

quotes.topic_title: Watching the agent build full-stack components
quotes.text: I think a lot of people just don't care about the code and are still able to build things, but we want to make the process transparent. We want to show people exactly what the agent is doing.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Counterintuitively argues that users can build without caring about code, while emphasizing transparency as a product principle.

quotes.topic_title: Watching the agent build full-stack components
quotes.text: Yeah, and actually, the way we built it is it's a multiplayer system.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Introduces a core mental model: treat the agent as a collaborator in a shared workspace rather than a separate tool.

quotes.topic_title: Watching the agent build full-stack components
quotes.text: So the agent in the code is structured as another user of the platform. So basically, we're both coding together.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Provides an implementable design pattern for agentic IDEs: model the AI as a first-class “user” in a multiplayer system.

quotes.topic_title: Current limitations and human-in-the-loop workflows
quotes.text: You can build MVPs. I think you can also start to get some initial users.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Sets a practical baseline for what AI-assisted building can reliably achieve today: MVP + early traction.

quotes.topic_title: Current limitations and human-in-the-loop workflows
quotes.text: For example, it's not very good at database migrations, and so we're trying to fix that.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete failure mode practitioners should plan around when iterating on AI-built apps.

quotes.topic_title: Current limitations and human-in-the-loop workflows
quotes.text: And so now it might change the database in a way that creates an error that's unrecoverable. And at that point, you might get stuck, especially if you don't know how to code.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Explains why iteration (not initial build) is the risky phase—schema changes can brick progress for non-coders.

quotes.topic_title: Current limitations and human-in-the-loop workflows
quotes.text: Yes or you can hire someone. We have a feature on the site called Bounties where you can hire human coders to kind of help you finish.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Offers a human-in-the-loop workflow: use AI for the first version, then escalate to paid experts to unblock/complete.

quotes.topic_title: Current limitations and human-in-the-loop workflows
quotes.text: We want to get to a point where the agent can go grab a human when it runs into a problem. I think that would be sick.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: A memorable “agent escalation” model: automation that proactively hands off to humans at the point of failure.

quotes.topic_title: QA loop, debugging, and cost/time comparison
quotes.text: Yeah. So now the agent is asking us, is the application running and showing the homepage?
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Highlights an AI-driven QA loop where the agent explicitly seeks confirmation of expected behavior before proceeding.

quotes.topic_title: QA loop, debugging, and cost/time comparison
quotes.text: Yeah, almost asking us to do a QA. I'll just say yes. So it found an error. So there's an error here and it's like there's a dumb warning, "I'm going to fix it."
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Shows a practical workflow where the agent detects issues and proactively fixes them, turning debugging into an interactive loop.

quotes.topic_title: QA loop, debugging, and cost/time comparison
quotes.text: A few days, I would say to a week. I mean, if you're really good, it might be hours but it probably would take me a few days. I would say I'm like decent engineer, it'll take you a few days.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Provides a concrete baseline for traditional engineering timelines to compare against AI-assisted prototyping speed.

quotes.topic_title: QA loop, debugging, and cost/time comparison
quotes.text: Yeah. Probably, I would estimate it like 15 cents or something like that.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Quantifies compute cost, reinforcing how AI can collapse the cost of building and iterating on prototypes.

quotes.topic_title: QA loop, debugging, and cost/time comparison
quotes.text: Here it is. And the agent was like, "Okay, this is looking good, completed it if you want to deploy it." But I'm like, "Okay, I'm going to test it first."
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Emphasizes a disciplined ship workflow: even when the agent says it’s ready, you still validate before deployment.

quotes.topic_title: Using the app and agent-assisted operations
quotes.text: So I'm going to ask the agent, how do I log into the admin panel?
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Shows a practical workflow where operational/admin tasks are handled conversationally by querying the agent instead of hunting through docs or code.

quotes.topic_title: Using the app and agent-assisted operations
quotes.text: So it's not only builds things, it also maintains things.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Highlights a shift from AI as a one-off builder to an ongoing operator that can handle maintenance and ops tasks.

quotes.topic_title: Using the app and agent-assisted operations
quotes.text: In this case, it's actually doing SQL queries. It's not writing code to create an admin account for us.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Concrete example of agent-assisted operations: direct database actions for admin setup rather than traditional engineering work.

quotes.topic_title: Using the app and agent-assisted operations
quotes.text: Our calculation is like, well, what if you made everyone developer? What does that look like?
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: A strategic mental model for product direction: expand the developer base rather than marginally improving existing engineers.

quotes.topic_title: Using the app and agent-assisted operations
quotes.text: And so I think that's going to be the case of software. As the costs go down, people will just make a lot more software to improve their lives and to improve their work and start more startups and all of that.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Counterintuitive demand model: lower software creation costs increase total software produced and consumed, not decrease it.

quotes.topic_title: How companies use Replit in practice
quotes.text: And that's kind of the problem with SaaS, like one size fits all.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: A crisp mental model for why teams build internal tools instead of buying SaaS—off-the-shelf software rarely matches specific workflows.

quotes.topic_title: How companies use Replit in practice
quotes.text: And so a lot of people are seeing it as sort of a SaaS replacement for in-house tools and things like that.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Actionable positioning: use Replit to quickly create tailored back-office tools that would otherwise require mismatched SaaS purchases.

quotes.topic_title: How companies use Replit in practice
quotes.text: So we've seen product managers build, like I said, like a v1 of an app and actually go out and test it with users.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: A practical methodology: PMs can prototype and validate with users before committing engineering resources.

quotes.topic_title: How companies use Replit in practice
quotes.text: So you are instead of unblocking product managers from having to need engineers for everything that they want to build so they can really build the v0 or v1 of the product.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: A counterintuitive org-design insight: shift early product discovery work from engineering dependency to PM-led building.

quotes.topic_title: How companies use Replit in practice
quotes.text: And we see sales engineers use Replit to spin up prototypes really quickly. So actually someone at X, formerly Twitter is on the partner engineering side of things, and he uses Replit agent to spin up applications and prototypes for customers to see how they can use the X API.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: A concrete example of using rapid prototyping to accelerate partner/customer adoption by demonstrating API use cases.

quotes.topic_title: Deploying to production and iteration workflow
quotes.text: We use Google Cloud. So we abstract all of that away from you, but we use Google Cloud behind the scenes.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: A concrete example of simplifying deployment for users by abstracting infrastructure while still relying on a major cloud provider.

quotes.topic_title: Deploying to production and iteration workflow
quotes.text: And there's almost like a new discipline called AI Computer interfaces. So sort of like HCI is now a ACI and turns out LLMs need interfaces that are actually quite different than humans.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable framework (ACI) for designing product interfaces optimized for AI agents rather than humans.

quotes.topic_title: Deploying to production and iteration workflow
quotes.text: They're trying to make them use human interfaces like Anthropic's computer use, but those are really expensive and you need to process all this images and video.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: A counterintuitive product insight: forcing AIs through human UI can be inefficient and costly compared to purpose-built agent interfaces.

quotes.topic_title: Deploying to production and iteration workflow
quotes.text: And that becomes your history, right? This was the v1 and now I'm working on this new feature, and it's almost like what engineers do in Git commit messages. By the way, it generates Git commit messages for everything that it does so you can roll back as well.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Actionable iteration workflow: treat AI-driven changes like standard engineering with history, commits, and rollback for safe experimentation.

quotes.topic_title: Deploying to production and iteration workflow
quotes.text: I said it's going to be society of models, like products will be made of a lot of different models, and it's quite a heavy engineering project.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: A strategic mental model for AI product architecture: multi-model “society” systems rather than a single monolithic model.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Census had a 10x increase in pipeline with a LinkedIn startup team.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Concrete performance benchmark showing how LinkedIn Ads can materially impact B2B pipeline when paired with the right support.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: For Webflow, after ramping up on LinkedIn in Q4, they had the highest marketing source revenue quarter to date.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Specific example of a timing-and-channel bet (ramping in Q4) translating into record marketing-sourced revenue.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: In tech, LinkedIn generated 2 to 5x higher return on ad spend than any other social media platforms.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Comparative ROAS claim that can guide channel allocation decisions for B2B tech marketers.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Audiences on LinkedIn have two times the buying power of the average web audience,
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A targeting rationale for why LinkedIn traffic may convert better despite higher CPMs.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: First of all, it's all the abstractions that we built.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: A product/engineering mental model: durable leverage comes from building strong abstractions as the foundation for higher-level capabilities.

quotes.topic_title: Technical stack: AI interfaces, tools, and models
quotes.text: And then we expose all of that infrastructure to the AI. And there's almost like a new discipline called AI Computer interfaces. So sort of like HCI is now a ACI and turns out LLMs need interfaces that are actually quite different than humans.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Introduces a practical framework shift—designing AI-native interfaces (ACI) rather than repurposing human UX patterns.

quotes.topic_title: Technical stack: AI interfaces, tools, and models
quotes.text: They're trying to make them use human interfaces like Anthropic's computer use, but those are really expensive and you need to process all this images and video. So instead, for the shell for example, we give it sort of a text representation of what the shell is doing at a certain increments for package installation.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Actionable design guidance: prefer structured/text tool outputs over pixel-based UI automation to reduce cost and complexity.

quotes.topic_title: Technical stack: AI interfaces, tools, and models
quotes.text: The most important model that we use is the Sonnet model from Claude, from Anthropic, and it is the best model at coding. So that's the model we use for coding, but we use models from OpenAI as well because a multi-agent system.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: A concrete stack pattern: pick best-in-class models per role and combine them in a multi-agent architecture.

quotes.topic_title: Technical stack: AI interfaces, tools, and models
quotes.text: I said it's going to be society of models, like products will be made of a lot of different models, and it's quite a heavy engineering project.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Memorable mental model that reframes AI products as engineered systems of multiple specialized models, not a single LLM.

quotes.topic_title: Technical stack: AI interfaces, tools, and models
quotes.text: So there's so many experimentation about what's the best way to give it a view on what's editing, how many files can you show it before it starts to hallucinate. And right now, it's more of an art than science, but it's becoming more and more like a science.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Counterintuitive operational insight: context presentation (e.g., number of files shown) can directly drive hallucinations, requiring systematic experimentation.

quotes.topic_title: Agents, autonomy, and product-builder implications
quotes.text: What I'm trying to say is that software, like agents being able to do software, is how AI gets more general because software runs our lives, runs the internet, runs our businesses. And so the more competent AI becomes that software, the more general they are in terms of what they can do.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: A clear mental model for why agentic coding is a key lever for AI generality and why product builders should pay attention.

quotes.topic_title: Agents, autonomy, and product-builder implications
quotes.text: Ultimately in software tech companies, everything that we're talking about need to eventually flush out in terms of code. And so what if the language becomes actually working prototypes and working applications?
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: A practical reframing of cross-functional communication: replace ambiguous handoffs with executable prototypes as the shared language.

quotes.topic_title: Agents, autonomy, and product-builder implications
quotes.text: So training that muscle I think is a good thing.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: Actionable advice that idea-generation (not execution) becomes the bottleneck as building gets cheaper and faster with AI.

quotes.topic_title: Agents, autonomy, and product-builder implications
quotes.text: I have this that's been called not by me, dubbed as Amjad's Law, which is the return on investment for learn to code is doubling every six months.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: A memorable heuristic for why even minimal coding/debugging literacy compounds rapidly as AI tooling improves.

quotes.topic_title: Agents, autonomy, and product-builder implications
quotes.text: I think learning a little bit of coding and not the traditional way of learning coding.
quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.context: A contrarian take on AI-native learning: focus on building/debugging with AI rather than front-loading traditional tooling and theory.
